I really hate that I have to call this game terrible, but sadly I do.  For me, it is almost unplayably bad, and I wish I had never wasted my money on it.

The gameplay mechanics are good; it is sometimes difficult to micromanage the orientation of platoons to keep them facing the enemy, and my recon helicopters have an annoying tendency to land whenever they're not actively moving, while I may want them to stay airborne to keep enemy units visible; the inability to set stances, and the rather awkward method of turning off individual weapons on individual units to keep control of who fires what, can be annoying, but I can generally get my units to do what I want.  The graphics are fantastic, making each unit distinct and identifiable.  The music fits the scene nicely, and the single player campaign storyline is nicely plausible.

So why do I call it terrible?  Becuase of the awful, terrible, abysmal AI.  In single player, the game becomes almost unplayable, all thanks to the AI's absolute omniscience.  Don't get me wrong, AIs have been able to see all the units on the field right back to the dawn of the RTS era, but it was generally not that big a deal.  In Wargame, however, recon is a central element of any army's tactics.  It requires careful attention to the type of recon vehicle, and equally careful scouting of suspected enemy strong points to avoid putting your recon vehicle in harms way.  The AI does none of that.  It just drops a full attack force directly on top of you, knowing exactly where all of your forces are at all times.  it is even worse in the campaign, where the AI will face you with overwhelming numbers in every mission, often pre-positioned in ambush sites that you can take no advantage of.  This severely reduces the tactics available, and ends up in a situation where the only way to make any sensible progress is by spamming the Quicksave key every time something doesn't go horribly wrong.

I play single player.  I enjoy playing single player so I can take my time and explore my options.  But this game makes single player a horrible, crippled experience that is more like a chore than a game.  For your own sanity, Avoid at all costs.

reviewText:
Excellent game. This is, in my view, the best of the Wargame series, despite being the oldest. The reason is that this is the only entry in the series with a proper single-player campaign.

The seuqels, Airland battle and Red Dragon, dropped the scripted campaign in favour of a dynamic campaign. On the face of it, a synamic campaign sounds great—it's different every time so you get infinite replayability, right? The problem is that the campaign battles in those games are little more than glorified skirmishes against AI bots. European Escalation, on the other hand, has a fully-scripted campaign where a real, human designer has taken the time to think carefully about the narative that links the missions together, the design of the maps to support the specific missions that take place there, and the placement of each individual enemy unit. The result is a much tighter, more compelling single-player experience. in fact, I would say that this game is one of the top three single-player RTS games of all time.

A key draw for the Wargame series is the multiplayer. European Escalation's multiplayer is good, but Airland Battle and Red Dragon are probably the better multiplayer games—they have more unit variety and more active communities. Multiplayer in Wargame is fantastic, so you should definitely check those two sequels. But anyone interested in a single-player RTS experience could do much much worse than giving European Escalation a shot.

reviewText:
So, after many different strategies and tactics, I have finally come to an unsatisfying conclusion. This game is a trainwreck.

Let me start off with the good parts about the game.

THE GOOD THINGS:
So, the graphics for a game on a scale such as this are amazing. The overall look of every unit is pretty good and you can clearly see that the developers did try to optimize the game as well.

There is a decent tutorial system in the game as well. From the first mission, it tells you what you must do and so on, and after the first few missions, the game lets your hand go and lets you think on your own.

That's just about it for the good things. Time for a good spank.

THE BAD THINGS:
So, let me start off with the enemy AI. In the Singleplayer Campaign, the AI seems to be an all-seeing entity that knows your every move, every tactic and attempted strategy, and immediately counters it, or makes it useless by annihilating your heaviest armored units. It's just impossible to fool this AI, no matter how hard I try, unless I guess where his line is the weakest and blast through there with whatever I can. This kills the overall fun of a fictional conflict RTS for me.

Next up: BALANCE
There are some serious balancing issues between units of similar roles in the game, like, the M60 Patton being unable to stand up to a T-60 or a T-72 whatsoever. As an example, I had four M60 Patton's engage against three T-60's, both stock versions and at full HP, however, the T-60's somehow, magically, one-shotted my Patton's, even though both groups had their frontal armor aimed at one another, AND to top it all off, my tanks never managed to hit them, despite the distance being probably optimal for late 20th century tank battles - 500 meters.

Third point: COMPUTER GETS AN UPPER HAND
At the start of every defense mission, the computer seems to have at least fifteen times more points that it can use to call upon reinforcements than the player. As an example, I was playing ABLE ARCHER's second mission, Ramstein Airbase or something like that, and I was able to call upon only three full squads of my finest armored units, M1 Abrams tanks. I placed them strategically where they were needed the most, but then the AI picked them all off almost 10 minutes after the start of the battle. The tanks were at full health, all of them had Corporal's stripes, but, they were just swarmed over by T-72's with missiles. I couldn't summon any other units because I didn't have a magical point income rate that the AI seemingly has.

Fourth: MAGIC INFANTRY
As the title says, the game has magic infantry units that can fire hand-held AT rockets on the move. No weapon that I know of is capable of being fired on the move. The result of this on-the-move shot should would fly away from its intended target, really far. And then Infantry is overpowered, by being able to one shot even heavy Main Battle Tanks.

Fifth point:
All the tanks are horribly underrated or overrated. The M1 Abrams seemingly has really bad equipment, while, to my knowledge, the Abrams was one of the best and most technologically advanced tanks of its time when it first came out. And the T-80 seems to be the single most capable tank of the game, able to utterly annihilate squads of Abrams and Leopard 2 tanks that are even outflanking it. Yes, this actually happened to me.

Sixth: TACTICS? I THINK NOT!
So, this game promotes a lot of thinking, but this clearly isn't a thinking man's game. It's a cheating man's game. What I mean is, no tactic has any value on the battlefield whatsoever. For example, I set my batallion in a formation where my flanks are stronger than my middle, to make sure that I can outflank my enemy and surround him in a powerful pincer move. But that doesn't work because the AI can do whatever the hell it wants and summon units out of nowhere to outflank my tanks and one-shot them all with incredible accuracy.

Seventh: ACCURACY
So, why do all of the player units suddenly have godawful accuracy and spotting range? I counted that at least 83% of all of my shots missed while they were in optimal engagement range, but for the AI - 67% was a miss at long range. The statistic is clearly showing how the AI wins in this and I am fully aware that the statistics for both factions are more or less balanced. It's still ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.

Eighth: MICRO- AND MACRO-MANAGEMENT
This game supports management on a small and massive scale, and it's applaudable. Games like this are a rarity and ones that execute it perfectly are a luxury among the rare ones, but Wargame isn't that luxury. The management is a huge distraction because your units have no versatility and they can't think for themselves. They're literally civilians given a gun and then shooting anything that moves, not trained soldiers that must do what they're told to do.

My personal verdict:
Don't waste your money on Wargame, get RUSE instead. Or better yet, if you want a Cold War-era game, get World in Conflict. It is a far better game, executed masterfully, unlike this poor excuse for a ''Wargame'' where everything is out of place.

NOTE: Don't give me that ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ that I must suck in this game. I've been playing RTS games for ages, and this game simply does NOT in ANY DARN WAY reward tactical/strategic thinking. It's all RNG.

reviewText:
I think the issue that bugs me the most is that units usually don't do what you tell them.
This game models unit morale: units will freak out and run if they come under heavy fire (or somebody stubs their toe on a rock), or become stunned and stuck in place when saturated with rockets. I'm not talking about that. I'll have perfectly healthy, calm units near a FOB or maneuvering across empty terrain and they can't follow simple instructions. I've had infantry refuse to get in transports right next to them, infantry refuse to move out of cover, units deciding to stand out in an open field when I've explicitly clicked on cover, tanks turn around and move in the opposite direction I wanted them to for no apparent reason, and units just simply not responding to move orders at all.

Speaking of moving and cover, apparently there is supposed to be some kind of automated snap-to-cover system in place. I've seen it work once or twice, but usually I end up with half the troops in a given unit hanging out in an open field as the rest of them hunker down in a tree line. The game lacks any way to tell units which direction to face or what kind of a formation to take; a major oversight given that the game seems to be designed to explicitly discourage unit micromanagement.

Which is frustrating because the AI is terrible. Units will fire on anything that gets within eyesight, regardless if they can hit it or not. I remember one instance where I told half a dozen helos to sweep an area. They moved about one hundred feet, saw a single T-55 tank way off in the distance, came to a screeching halt, and unloaded every single rocket at it. They did little, if any, damage to it and I had to empty out most of a FOB to rearm them. Anti-tank infantry will fire off every missile they have at anything even remotely in range, and given the computers indecisiveness this usually means they expend every single rocket (with zero effect) before the opfor vehicles get into a more reasonable range. (I know the player can 'turn off' the weapons of the units, but then it's just back to micromanaging everything again.)

That isn't to say the computer is smart - it's not, it's as dumb as a brick. The developers seem to have known this, so they compenstated (in the singleplayer campaign at least) by putting an absolute metric fudge ton of enemy units on the maps. Players are easily outnumbered four to one, by my estimate. The only counter to this is just throw massive groups of units at the computer - the enemy can't call in new units, you can - but this mostly ruins the entire 'strategy' element of the game. Your units are as dumb as the computers (see above), so any attempt to set up kill zones or perform interesting maneuvers is usually thwarted by some IFVs or tanks or something deciding to wander off on their own, or charge in, or just plain not move.

To add to the problem the enemy tend to be super-human. One particularly notable example I can recall: I was moving into a small town and a single enemy infantry squad had set up in a house on an outer corner. Nothing special; just some rifles, grenades, and some RPGs spread among about twenty soldiers. Ten minutes later I had lost sixteen Leopard 2 tanks, and managed to whittle the unit (which had been under direct fire from the tanks the entire time) down to two guys. I sent in four Huey gunships to clean up and lost them all within five seconds to two guys with rifles who were hunkered down in a pile of gravel and splintered 2x4's. I shelled it a bit with artillery and ran away. I don't know if I ever actually cleaned them out.

Oh yeah, and the maps are heavily scripted. It varies from map to map, of course, but usually there is a massive attack wave or reinforcements, or something that will spawn when the player invades a given objective or moves past a specific point. One of the early missions the player is supposed to secure a collapsed bridge with a command unit early on. Thing is, if you never capture that objective the reenforcement wave never comes in, which leaves the player with as much time as they like to build up a massive force or just bypassing the objective entirely. It feels like cheating, but in some cases it seems like the only way to complete the map.

This game tries to sell itself as the ultimate strategy game but fails miserably. It seems like the developers couldn't decide if the player should micromanage their army or not, and as a result the units are stupid and the controls are frustratingly incomplete. The graphics are pretty good but given that this is the second game they made with this engine (R.U.S.E. being the first) I'm not surprised. I am extremely impressed by the level of unit detail they've built in, which makes the badly designed controls and pitiful AI seem all the more vexing.

Not recommended. I suggest World in Conflict as an alternative, if you're a fan of 198X-era wargaming. It's not nearly as detailed in terms of units but the singleplayer plays a lot better. In my opinion anyway.

reviewText:
Wargame took me by suprise: when I first got it, I didn't like it: no idea what I was doing, no idea why my tanks couldn't hit anything, no idea how to heal my tanks...and every loss was quite permanent.

If an LP hadn't taught me the tricks and tactics, I wouldn't never had bothered with the game. As it stands, the game is just what I want in an RTS: APM and perfect build trees timed down to the second won't make you a boss here: it's all about ambushing the enemy's expensive tanks with cheap -but-powerful infantry, or blowing those infantry to pieces with some mortars, or catching enemy supply trucks off-guard with gunships.

People who can't grasp that will see their super-tanks get torn to shreds by infantry with AT grenades, and I love it.

While I appreciate the realism (persistent army between levels, level-up for survivors, fuel, ammo, logistics supply and command centers, lots of hide and seek), which is very nice and made me quite addicted for a while, I eventually quit playing for two basic reasons:

1. At the campaign, you have very limited troops and resources, while the CPU can spawn units forever as long as they have the reinforcements points. So you either rush or die. I don't appreciate STRATEGY when you have to rush.
2. Multiplayer, well ... you know how RTS multiplayer go, but in wargame it is worse because of the limited everything, so only the hardcore players will do anything, a casual player like me have no chance.
3. There are zillions of bugs on the border areas. For instance, enemy units that retreat (rout) outside the map cannot be easilly target, and worse yet, they might just stay there. I lost a couple of cames because some stupid enemy unit retreated near a reinforcement point and any/all supply truck I called in was immediatly captured, but since they spawn outside the map, I could not send troops to capture them back. Some enemy units go to far outside the map you can't even scout/see to try and siege them, wtf

So: campaign: you are infinitelly capped against an infinite oponent, so you have to win while you have troops; multiplayer: hardcore made even more hardcore. No, thanks.

reviewText: WarGame: European Escalation. Here is a game that has what I wanted in a strategy game. Unit formations, experianced units that carry over and a touch of thinking on how to complele a mission. here is the problem. You have no advanage what-so-ever. yes you may have a unit of heavy tanks supported by anti air and either gunships or artillery. But when that really means something your units don't use the initiative thats been given them. such as 10-1 odds where you have ten units firing at four, the out com should be opfor loss. No the same four vehicle unit rides right up to you one and only command unit holding open your reenforcement window and takes it out with a guided missile at point black right infront of all your heavy tanks, anti- armor and and duel purpose anti air artillery. There goes the reenforcements needed to resupply and and other command you its you wanted to purchace. As for supplies thats the hardest thing to use sence every thing runds on supplies, there isn't enough of it to utilize to either complete all the objectives in the time alloted or to hold out with. AI is horrible when you have a hardden veteran who panics at the first initial contact and routs right but the command unit it was protecting thus exposing it. I would think a unit that's been through so much fighting would realize that I've survived this long in this heavy tank that my crew can it a flea at three miles away while it is moving wouldn't panic when the action starts. And lets not forget the coversystem for vehicles. You can hole them up in a forest or a town but the element of surprize seemes to be the trade off for range. Once in cover the range is reduced for some silly reason. and when the enemy spots you with recon a tank unit can roll right up and shell you at the same distance you could normally fire. Don't get me wrong. This game has a tutorial, the first campaign under the west germans allows you to learn how to use units. But when you get to gunships, they just don't seem to hack it when fighting softer targets. lets also not forget to mention units sitting OFF MAP and still controlling territory and firing away at your units WHO CANNOT FIRE BACK. Ignored the indications where you set the objectives and FOB next to these out of reach tangos? If the Developers would take alook at these flaws and probably patch them maybe this game would have a chance? I'm not recomending this game to those who want a game where they can sit back and relax. this has all the qualities for Rage quitting. Which I've been doing for four days straight since buying it and the whole collection. For Fast play and russhing with no strategy. I recomend it because if you don't care about your losses or the chance to carry over experianced units. then build all your tanks and rush them. the russian AI does it.

reviewText:
This game has great concept but is poorly executed in some parts. Graphics are nice but where it fails is gameplay, it's just tedious and no fun at all. It was intended as a mixture beetween macro and micro managing your troops on the battlefield but the big problem is they can't effectively fight without your constant surveillance. I.e.  infantry won't take cover in nearby woods if engaged by tanks by itself, you have to tell them to. You have to tell your troops every small detail what to do and how to do it and in real time with so many troops it's simply not possible. Also the troops often execute your orders clumsily what only adds to the problem. The lack of any ai behaviour (beyond starting to fire and fleeing) in your troops is what ruins the game for me.

Non-armed infantry transport and supply trucks are a major nuisance as well since you can't order them to leave the battlefield once they have fulfilled their function. You should be able to tell them to leave the battlefield via access routes.

Also the armory is not easy to navigate and find troops you need, and having so many type of infantry cards with different transport is also clumsy execution imo. They should have put only infantry by type and then ask you to join desired transport card to them. This would make that part of armory much more clear and less messy.

Command vehicle model for controling sector is not good either imo, you can spend plenty of time searching for a single hidden command vehicle while you have many troops stationed in the sector yourself, they should have stuck to the control point capping other game use.

I do like some aspects of the game like having to supply your troops, limited number of troops ,access points, terrain effects etc however altogether they don't make a satisfactory game experience in a single player campaign... In multiplayer all players have the same hendicap and problems so I guess most of the problem are nullified however if you're looking for a good single player experience like I did I would advise you to steer clear from this one.

I bought this game a while back when it was on sale, hoping it would be similar to R.U.S.E. It is to some degree but this game kinda kicks itself in the behind by forgetting the basics of an open world RTS.

The game is terribly restrictive despite being an open map RTS, your troops are goverened by 4 factors - Physchological state, ammo, fuel, repair status. Fuel runs out within mere minutes, you cant traverse  the map without having to refuel once or twice. Most missions do not even give you the ability to refuel your army unless you are lucky enough to capture a suply depot. So far it makes sense doesnt it, but here is the restrictive part.

As expected the A.I. is automatically in control of these supply depots and so they are heavily reinforced, making you use tactical moves to beat the A.I. However you run out of fuel in doing so, so you are forced to go in head on. Ta Da problem is here. The A.I. being a computer some how has 100% accuracy with their weapons so the only way is to outgun them in order to win...oh dear, you are always out gunned in the first place so here is 1st catch 22 situation.

Secdonly you do not really have the choice of what units to deploy, there is a pre-determined list of which you can select (unlock) units or not.

Its a tediout game, not worth the time and trouble. Buy R.U.S.E which is absolutely fantastic, and is extremely similar to this game in terms of game interface and strategy requirements.

Finally one aspect which really didnt make sense to me...you are play as part of NATO...a group of countries whos military power and resources easily rivals that of the USSR and its allies...why on earth is the game giving you only 5 tanks to take on 40 tanks??

It would have been a far better game if there was some way of obtaining more units, maybe in the style of World In Conflict or even R.U.S.E. Instead cant help but feel this game suffers from COD syndrome...one man army against the world.

AVOID THIS GAME LIKE THE PLAGUE!!

I understand that i may have only played this game for 1.5 hours on record...however it has been much longer, and being an RTS fantatic...do understand the difference between good ones and bad ones as have experienced them.

Wargame: EE is what RUSE should have been in the first place: a game that focuses on massive, accurate-to-scale battlefields, a diverse roster of units to choose from, and realistic tactics.  There's no basebuilding, no offsite artillery or airstrikes, no fancy RUSE cards - all you get are the units you spawn in and what you call in as reinforcements.  The units handle rather realistically too - many of the units have the strengths and weaknesses they have in real-life.

Keep in mind though, it's not completely realistic.  Some abstractions were made for the sake of balance, a good example being the supply units.  Any type of supply unit and repair, refuel, and rearm anything on the field, until it runs out of supply points.

Overall, if you're tired of the typical base-building RTSes or games that are more about your APM/ build orders, then you'd definately find the game to be a fun change of pace.

Coming from the same developers as R.U.S.E., Wargame: European Escalation may feel familiar in its large scale. Fully real-time, Wargame is a RTS game focusing on a fictional escalation of the Cold War into a full-scale war between NATO and the Warsaw Pact.
This game features zero base-building. Positioning (flanking, cover, ambushes) is everything: several well-placed infantry units in a forest can wreck enemy tanks, and a pair of hidden heavy tanks can tear up targets from long range. Deployment of units is handled with command points, gained through control of sectors.
The starting allocation of units is determined by your active deck- one deck for the NATO player, and one deck for the PACT player. Decks are expanded through Command Stars, gained through campaign progress and multiplayer EXP. New units, such as the T-80 tank or the ubiquitous M1 Abrams, are purchased with Command Stars.
The game is tough and has a steep learning curve, but few games are more satisfying to master.

I love this game. Why?
First off, let me state that it is not forgiving. How is that good? Allow me to explain.
Because it is not forgiving and punishes every error you make, you feel the need to always play at your best, lest some AI or player exploit said mistakes. That's what keeps this game fun. You have to be quick witted and find yourself always thinking ahead. It's not StarCraft II where one may spam production of resources and single units for a cause. You are given a handful of units and are practically ordered to work with what you've got to accomplish the objective. Attrition takes a heavy toll for all combatants in this game, only furthering your need to ensure you get it right the first time.

The games major strong points are its challenging AI, extremely fun multiplayer, and never-tiring gameplay.

The gameplay is among the most realistic available. Is it lifelike? No. However, the weapons, damage, and effects represents what you'd expect a tank shell to do to a light armor vehicle. Send it up in a shower of sparks and smoke. This only enforces the need to protect your supporting units and counter opposing units in a rock-paper-scissors-spock game of real time chess. Each unit has its strengths and weaknesses. Each unit can be used to determine victory or outright failure in a match. You're immediately caught in the illusion that you're fighting to protect not only your pride as a commander on the battlefield, but that you're fighting for the lives of your units which will bring you an ever-so-sweet victory at the expense of your enemy's downfall. Winner takes all in this game.

The campaign explores a Cold War scenario where NATO and the Warsaw Pact go head to head. If history is your kind of thing, and the Cold War happens to be mine, then this is certainly the game for you.

Get it. I guarantee you won't regret it.

reviewText:
Wargame: European Escalation and its later game Wargame: Red Dragon are shining examples of what RTS games should be. Well designed and masterfully researched, these games are a must own for an RTS fan. If you want to recreate what the cold war played out would be like.... Wargame. If you want to learn about the capabilities of different military vehicals from both sides of the cold war....Wargame.

On a gameplay front, the game has a short, but steep learning curve, and only minimal tutorials. The difficulty curve on the other hand is rather....monolithic. The single player campaign is challenging and fun, rewarding those that really invest time in the game. Mechanically, the game is very functional. I wish some of the AI were a tad sharper or more clear, but it all works very well. While later games add new mechanics and refinements to the Wargame system, European Escalation is still the most functional of the games and the best way to begin a Wargame experience (Aircraft in Red Dragon operate by some sort of gypsy targeting, difficult to use well).

Don't be discouraged by the difficulty of the campaign, or the initially confusing combat; once you understand how to play this game it is one of the goodies!

Have you ever wondered how it would be to command Warsaw Pact motorized rifle brigade? Do you think you could stop Soviet onslaught with your own NATO battalion? Ask yourself no more, but purchase this game.
A great mix of an RTS with card game, where you can create your own unit, and then send it to combat against enemy, both AI, or human player.
Despite being an RTS and not mil sim, with all it's simplifications this is the most realistic game of it's genre (and probably the only such game).
It allows you to become commander of brigade size force of either Warsaw Pact or NATO, and take part in some fictional campaigns, or try your skill in multiplayer. Whether you want to rush with 20 T-55, or 2 T-80, you will feel like true commander would have felt during actual engagements. You will face the same decisions, choices and challenges and have to answer them in correct way to achieve victory.
If you consider Combat Mission tactical, and Total War strategical, Wargame is the operational level of war. It is like Total War with only battles left. And those are battles in the last moment when most modern equipement was used the same way it was used during World War II. Coming from the same developers as R.U.S.E., Wargame: European Escalation may feel familiar in its large scale. Fully real-time, Wargame is a RTS game focusing on a fictional escalation of the Cold War into a full-scale war between NATO and the Warsaw Pact.
This game features zero base-building. Positioning (flanking, cover, ambushes) is everything: several well-placed infantry units in a forest can wreck enemy tanks, and a pair of hidden heavy tanks can tear up targets from long range. Deployment of units is handled with command points, gained through control of sectors.
The starting allocation of units is determined by your active deck- one deck for the NATO player, and one deck for the PACT player. Decks are expanded through Command Stars, gained through campaign progress and multiplayer EXP. New units, such as the T-80 tank or the ubiquitous M1 Abrams, are purchased with Command Stars.
The game is tough and has a steep learning curve, but few games are more satisfying to master.

Keep in mind though, it's not completely realistic.  Some abstractions were made for the sake of balance, a good example being the supply units.  Any type of supply unit and repair, refuel, and rearm anything on the field, until it runs out of supply points.

reviewText:
Wargame: European Escalation and its later game Wargame: Red Dragon are shining examples of what RTS games should be. Well designed and masterfully researched, these games are a must own for an RTS fan. If you want to recreate what the cold war played out would be like.... Wargame. If you want to learn about the capabilities of different military vehicals from both sides of the cold war....Wargame.

On a gameplay front, the game has a short, but steep learning curve, and only minimal tutorials. The difficulty curve on the other hand is rather....monolithic. The single player campaign is challenging and fun, rewarding those that really invest time in the game. Mechanically, the game is very functional. I wish some of the AI were a tad sharper or more clear, but it all works very well. While later games add new mechanics and refinements to the Wargame system, European Escalation is still the most functional of the games and the best way to begin a Wargame experience (Aircraft in Red Dragon operate by some sort of gypsy targeting, difficult to use well).

Don't be discouraged by the difficulty of the campaign, or the initially confusing combat; once you understand how to play this game it is one of the goodies!
